sourcing.instructions: Ca: Calcium metal can be sourced from chemical supply companies. Li: Lithium can be obtained from lithium carbonate available in specialized chemical suppliers. Si: Silicon can be sourced from semiconductor material suppliers. Sm: Samarium can be purchased from rare earth metal suppliers. Y: Yttrium can be obtained from metal suppliers or chemical suppliers.

1. Measure out 2.0 g of Ca, 4.0 g of Li, 8.0 g of Si, 1.0 g of Sm, and 1.0 g of Y using an analytical balance. 2. Place all measured materials in a ceramic mortar and pestle. 3. preparation.raw_text: 1. Measure out 2.0 g of Ca, 4.0 g of Li, 8.0 g of Si, 1.0 g of Sm, and 1.0 g of Y using an analytical balance. 2. Place all measured materials in a ceramic mortar and pestle. 3. Grind the materials together thoroughly to achieve a uniform powder mixture. 4. Transfer the mixture to a clean crucible suitable for high-temperature processing.

steps: 1. Preheat a furnace to 1000°C. 2. Place the crucible containing the powder mixture into the furnace. 3. Maintain the temperature at 1000°C for 4 hours to ensure complete reaction and formation of the desired compound.
heating.raw_text: 1. Preheat a furnace to 1000°C. 2. Place the crucible containing the powder mixture into the furnace. 3. Maintain the temperature at 1000°C for 4 hours to ensure complete reaction and formation of the desired compound.

steps: 1. After the heating period, turn off the furnace and allow it to cool down naturally. 2. Wait until the temperature drops below 200°C before removing the crucible from the furnace. 3. Allow the crucible to cool to room temperature (approximately 1-2 hours).
cooling.raw_text: 1. After the heating period, turn off the furnace and allow it to cool down naturally. 2. Wait until the temperature drops below 200°C before removing the crucible from the furnace. 3. Allow the crucible to cool to room temperature (approximately 1-2 hours).

steps: 1. Once cooled, carefully extract the solid sample from the crucible. 2. Inspect the sample for any imperfections. 3. If necessary, use fine-grit sandpaper to smooth any rough edges. 4. Optionally, apply a sealant or protective coating if required for the application.
